what: Performs a differential item functioning analysis of polytomous items using ANCOVA — ANCOVA.dif
title: Performs a differential item functioning analysis of polytomous items using ANCOVA — ANCOVA.dif
text: Differential item functioning analysis polytomous items via ANCOVA Differential item functioning analysis polytomous items via ANCOVA

title: Performs a differential item functioning analysis of polytomous items using ANCOVA — ANCOVA.dif
code: ANCOVA.dif(x, Group, Trait)  ANCOVA.dif(x, Group, Trait)

title: Performs a differential item functioning analysis of polytomous items using ANCOVA — ANCOVA.dif
text: x data frame containing items. items scored direction. Group factor indicating group membership Trait vector containing measures trait. may total scores across items, mean item scores, factor scores, IRT person measures.

title: Performs a differential item functioning analysis of polytomous items using ANCOVA — ANCOVA.dif
code: library(lordif) #> Error in library(lordif): there is no package called ‘lordif’ data(Anxiety) #> Warning: data set ‘Anxiety’ not found x <- Anxiety #> Error: object 'Anxiety' not found  ### Remove unwanted columns x <- Anxiety[-c(1,3)] #> Error: object 'Anxiety' not found  ### Calculate the Trait score Trait <- rowMeans(Anxiety[2:30]) #> Error: object 'Anxiety' not found  ### Place the trait score in the first column, followed by the group, and then the items x <- cbind(Trait, x) #> Error: object 'Trait' not found  ### Perform the dif analysis out <- ANCOVA.dif(x, Group, Trait)  #> Error: object 'Trait' not found out #> Error: object 'out' not found library(lordif) #> Error in library(lordif): there is no package called ‘lordif’ data(Anxiety) #> Warning: data set ‘Anxiety’ not found x <- Anxiety #> Error: object 'Anxiety' not found  ### Remove unwanted columns x <- Anxiety[-c(1,3)] #> Error: object 'Anxiety' not found  ### Calculate the total score with simple summation Trait <- rowMeans(Anxiety[2:30]) #> Error: object 'Anxiety' not found  ### Place the trait score in the first column, followed by the group, and then the items x <- cbind(Trait, x) #> Error: object 'Trait' not found  ### Perform the dif analysis out <- ANCOVA.dif(x, Group, Trait) #> Error: object 'Trait' not found out #> Error: object 'out' not found

what: Performs a differential item functioning analysis of polytomous items using ANCOVA — Rasch.DIF
title: Performs a differential item functioning analysis of polytomous items using ANCOVA — Rasch.DIF
text: Differential item functioning analysis polytomous items via ANCOVA

title: Performs a differential item functioning analysis of polytomous items using ANCOVA — Rasch.DIF
code: Rasch.DIF(std.res, group, thetas)

title: Performs a differential item functioning analysis of polytomous items using ANCOVA — Rasch.DIF
text: std.res data frame containing standardized residuals Rasch analysis group factor indicating group membership thetas vector containing measures trait. may total scores across items, mean item scores, factor scores, IRT person measures.

title: Performs a differential item functioning analysis of polytomous items using ANCOVA — Rasch.DIF
code: library(lordif) #> Error in library(lordif): there is no package called ‘lordif’ data(Anxiety) #> Warning: data set ‘Anxiety’ not found dd <- Simple.Rasch(Anxiety[4:32] - 1, "PCM2") #> Error in library(psych): there is no package called ‘psych’ dd$std.residuals <- data.frame(dd$std.residuals) #> Error: object 'dd' not found ### Perform the dif analysis out <- Rasch.DIF(dd$std.residuals, Anxiety$gender, dd$thetas[,1])  #> Error: object 'dd' not found out #> Error: object 'out' not found

what: Rasch analysis of polytomous items with the partial credit model — RaschItemAnalysis
title: Rasch analysis of polytomous items with the partial credit model — RaschItemAnalysis
text: Basic Rasch analysis polytomous items using partial credit model. function wrapper PCM() function eRm package. purpose function simplify Rasch analysis process produce output users typically want.

title: Rasch analysis of polytomous items with the partial credit model — RaschItemAnalysis
code: RaschItemAnalysis(x)

title: Rasch analysis of polytomous items with the partial credit model — RaschItemAnalysis
text: x data frame containing items lowest response category scored 0

title: Rasch analysis of polytomous items with the partial credit model — RaschItemAnalysis
text: output list containing results analysis.

title: Rasch analysis of polytomous items with the partial credit model — RaschItemAnalysis
code: library(lordif) #> Error in library(lordif): there is no package called ‘lordif’ data(Anxiety) #> Warning: data set ‘Anxiety’ not found Anxiety <- Anxiety[4:32] - 1  #> Error: object 'Anxiety' not found  ## Fit the partial credit model myoutput <- RaschItemAnalysis(x = Anxiety) #> Error in loadNamespace(x): there is no package called ‘eRm’ ls(myoutput) #> Warning: ‘myoutput’ converted to character string #> Error in as.environment(pos): no item called "myoutput" on the search list myoutput$Infit.outfit  #> Error: object 'myoutput' not found

code: SchepersCluster(x, nitems)

title: Item selection based on inter-item covariances — SchepersCluster
text: x Data frame containing items scored direction nitems number items select (value lower four)

title: Item selection based on inter-item covariances — SchepersCluster
text: list containing () two items constitute core, (b) data frame containing scale statistics, (c) names items included scale

title: Item selection based on inter-item covariances — SchepersCluster
code: library(lordif) #> Error in library(lordif): there is no package called ‘lordif’ data(Anxiety) #> Warning: data set ‘Anxiety’ not found SchepersCluster(Anxiety[4:32], 5) #> Error in library(psych): there is no package called ‘psych’

what: Rasch analysis of dichotomous or polytomous items — Simple.Rasch
title: Rasch analysis of dichotomous or polytomous items — Simple.Rasch
text: Basic Rasch analysis dichotomous polytomous items. function wrapper tam.mml() function TAM package principal() function psych package. purpose function simplify Rasch analysis process produce output plots applied beginner users typically want.

title: Rasch analysis of dichotomous or polytomous items — Simple.Rasch
code: Simple.Rasch(raschdata, irtmodel)

title: Rasch analysis of dichotomous or polytomous items — Simple.Rasch
text: raschdata data frame containing items lowest response category scored 0 irtmodel Rasch model, can "PCM", "PCM2" "RSM".

title: Rasch analysis of dichotomous or polytomous items — Simple.Rasch
text: output list containing results analysis.

title: Rasch analysis of dichotomous or polytomous items — Simple.Rasch
code: library(TAM) #> Error in library(TAM): there is no package called ‘TAM’ library(lordif) #> Error in library(lordif): there is no package called ‘lordif’ data(Anxiety) #> Warning: data set ‘Anxiety’ not found Anxiety <- Anxiety - 1 #> Error: object 'Anxiety' not found  ## Fit the rating scale model myoutput <- Simple.Rasch(raschdata = Anxiety[4:32], irtmodel = "RSM") #> Error in library(psych): there is no package called ‘psych’ ls(myoutput) #> Warning: ‘myoutput’ converted to character string #> Error in as.environment(pos): no item called "myoutput" on the search list myoutput$item.fit #> Error: object 'myoutput' not found  #' ## Fit the partial credit model myoutput <- Simple.Rasch(raschdata = Anxiety[4:32], irtmodel = "PCM2") #> Error in library(psych): there is no package called ‘psych’ ls(myoutput) #> Warning: ‘myoutput’ converted to character string #> Error in as.environment(pos): no item called "myoutput" on the search list myoutput$item.fit #> Error: object 'myoutput' not found

what: Fits all possible combinations of k items from a pool of n items to a single-factor model. — best_items
title: Fits all possible combinations of k items from a pool of n items to a single-factor model. — best_items
text: function can useful selecting items larger pool items. function allows comparisons possible combinations k items pool respect fit single factor model reliability. function works best number possible unique combinations items less 5000. becomes extremely slow 5000 possible combinations.

title: Fits all possible combinations of k items from a pool of n items to a single-factor model. — best_items
code: best_items(x, k)

title: Fits all possible combinations of k items from a pool of n items to a single-factor model. — best_items
text: x data frame containing items. k number items selected.

title: Fits all possible combinations of k items from a pool of n items to a single-factor model. — best_items
code: library(lordif) #> Error in library(lordif): there is no package called ‘lordif’ data(Anxiety) #> Warning: data set ‘Anxiety’ not found ## Say we want to select the best four items from the first 15 Anxiety items ## The choose() function shows how many possible unique combinations there are choose(ncol(Anxiety[4:15], 4)) #> Error in ncol(Anxiety[4:15], 4): unused argument (4) out <- best_items(Anxiety[4:15], 6)  #> Error: object 'Anxiety' not found out #> Error: object 'out' not found

what: Fits all possible combinations of k items from a pool of n items to a single-factor model using parallel processing. — best_itemsPar
title: Fits all possible combinations of k items from a pool of n items to a single-factor model using parallel processing. — best_itemsPar
text: function can useful selecting items larger pool items. function allows comparisons possible combinations k items pool respect fit single factor model reliability. function works best number possible unique combinations items less 5000. becomes extremely slow 5000 possible combinations. function employs parallel processing speed process, remains slow.

title: Fits all possible combinations of k items from a pool of n items to a single-factor model using parallel processing. — best_itemsPar
code: best_itemsPar(x, k)

title: Fits all possible combinations of k items from a pool of n items to a single-factor model using parallel processing. — best_itemsPar
text: x data frame containing items. name data frame must x must loaded global environment function run. k number items selected.

title: Fits all possible combinations of k items from a pool of n items to a single-factor model using parallel processing. — best_itemsPar
code: library(lordif) #> Error in library(lordif): there is no package called ‘lordif’ data(Anxiety) #> Warning: data set ‘Anxiety’ not found ## Say we want to select the best four items from the first 15 Anxiety items ## The choose() function shows how many possible unique combinations there are choose(ncol(Anxiety[4:15], 4)) #> Error in ncol(Anxiety[4:15], 4): unused argument (4)  ## Store the data frame in the global environment as x x <- Anxiety[4:15] #> Error: object 'Anxiety' not found out <- best_itemsPar(x, 6)  #> Error: object 'x' not found out #> Error: object 'out' not found

what: Confirmatory factor analysis of ordinal items with WLSMV estimation — cfa_wlsmv
title: Confirmatory factor analysis of ordinal items with WLSMV estimation — cfa_wlsmv

code: cfa_wlsmv(x)

text: output list containing results analysis.

title: Confirmatory factor analysis of ordinal items with WLSMV estimation — cfa_wlsmv
code: library(psych) #> Error in library(psych): there is no package called ‘psych’ data(bfi) #> Warning: data set ‘bfi’ not found  cfa_wlsmv(x) #> Error: object 'x' not found

title: Inter-item correlations — cor.item
text: Statistics related inter-item correlations items Statistics related inter-item correlations items

title: Inter-item correlations — cor.item
code: cor.item(x)  cor.item(x)

title: Inter-item correlations — cor.item
text: x Data frame containing items scored direction

title: Inter-item correlations — cor.item
text: list containing () inter-item correlation matrix, (b) item average correlation remaining items, (c) squared multiple correlation item remaining items, (d) average inter-item correlation across items, (e) median inter-item correlation across items. list containing () inter-item correlation matrix, (b) item average correlation remaining items, (c) squared multiple correlation item remaining items, (d) average inter-item correlation across items, (e) median inter-item correlation across items.

title: Inter-item correlations — cor.item
code: library(lordif) #> Error in library(lordif): there is no package called ‘lordif’ data(Anxiety) #> Warning: data set ‘Anxiety’ not found cor.item(Anxiety[4:32]) #> Error: object 'Anxiety' not found library(lordif) #> Error in library(lordif): there is no package called ‘lordif’ data(Anxiety) #> Warning: data set ‘Anxiety’ not found cor.item(Anxiety[4:32]) #> Error: object 'Anxiety' not found

what: Detection of statistically significant differential item functioning via ANCOVA of standardized Rasch residuals — dif.Rasch
title: Detection of statistically significant differential item functioning via ANCOVA of standardized Rasch residuals — dif.Rasch
text: Detection statistically significant differential item functioning via ANCOVA standardized Rasch residuals

title: Detection of statistically significant differential item functioning via ANCOVA of standardized Rasch residuals — dif.Rasch
code: dif.Rasch(std.residuals, Theta, Group)

title: Detection of statistically significant differential item functioning via ANCOVA of standardized Rasch residuals — dif.Rasch
text: std.residuals matrix data frame containing standardized residuals Rasch analysis Theta vector containing thetas (person measures) Group vector (factor) containing group membership

title: Detection of statistically significant differential item functioning via ANCOVA of standardized Rasch residuals — dif.Rasch
text: DIF results

title: Detection of statistically significant differential item functioning via ANCOVA of standardized Rasch residuals — dif.Rasch
code: library(TAM) #> Error in library(TAM): there is no package called ‘TAM’ library(lordif) #> Error in library(lordif): there is no package called ‘lordif’ Anxiety <- Anxiety - 1 #> Error: object 'Anxiety' not found  ## Fit the partial credit model myRasch <- Simple.Rasch(Anxiety[ , 4:32], "PCM2") #> Error in library(psych): there is no package called ‘psych’  ## Perform the DIF analysis using the standardized residuals, Rasch person measure and group as input dif.Rasch(myRasch$std.residuals, myRasch$thetas[,1], Anxiety$gender) #> Error: object 'myRasch' not found

what: Performs a differential item functioning analysis of polytomous items using ANCOVA — dif.ancova
title: Performs a differential item functioning analysis of polytomous items using ANCOVA — dif.ancova
text: Differential item functioning analysis polytomous items via ANCOVA

title: Performs a differential item functioning analysis of polytomous items using ANCOVA — dif.ancova
code: dif.ancova(data, Trait, Group)

title: Performs a differential item functioning analysis of polytomous items using ANCOVA — dif.ancova
text: data data frame containing items. items scored direction. Trait vector containing measures trait. may total scores across items, mean item scores, factor scores, IRT person measures. Group factor indicating group membership

title: Performs a differential item functioning analysis of polytomous items using ANCOVA — dif.ancova
code: library(lordif) #> Error in library(lordif): there is no package called ‘lordif’ data(Anxiety) #> Warning: data set ‘Anxiety’ not found ### Perform the dif analysis out <- dif.ancova(Anxiety[4:32], rowSums(Anxiety[4:32]), Anxiety$gender)  #> Error: object 'Anxiety' not found out #> Error: object 'out' not found

what: Identify influential cases and examine their impact — influential.cases
title: Identify influential cases and examine their impact — influential.cases
text: Calculates generalized Cook's Distance statistics. Removes specified number cases largest gCD values. Compares factor loadings, fit statistics reliabilities full data set filtered data set.

title: Identify influential cases and examine their impact — influential.cases
code: influential.cases(x, ncases = 1)

title: Identify influential cases and examine their impact — influential.cases
text: x Data frame containing items ncases number cases treat influential. value can set 1 adjusted subsequent analyses.

title: Identify influential cases and examine their impact — influential.cases
text: list containing () factor loadings, (b) fit statistics single factor solution, (c) Cronbach alpha coefficients full filtered data sets.

title: Identify influential cases and examine their impact — influential.cases
code: library(lordif) #> Error in library(lordif): there is no package called ‘lordif’ data(Anxiety) #> Warning: data set ‘Anxiety’ not found influential.cases(Anxiety[1:250, 4:32], 1) #> Error: object 'Anxiety' not found

what: Item selection based on McDonald's item information statistic — info.select
title: Item selection based on McDonald's item information statistic — info.select
text: item selection procedure based item information statistics.

title: Item selection based on McDonald's item information statistic — info.select
code: info.select(x, nitems)

title: Item selection based on McDonald's item information statistic — info.select
text: x data frame containing items nitems number items retain scale

title: Item selection based on McDonald's item information statistic — info.select
text: function sequentially removes item lowest information statistic pool items. output list containing () data frame shows step item selection process number items removed, name item removed, reliability scale; (b) names items retained; (c) coefficient omega final scale, (d) coefficient alpha final scale.

title: Item selection based on McDonald's item information statistic — info.select
code: library(lordif) #> Error in library(lordif): there is no package called ‘lordif’ data(Anxiety) #> Warning: data set ‘Anxiety’ not found info.select(Anxiety[4:32], 5) #> Error in loadNamespace(x): there is no package called ‘psych’

title: McDonald's item information statistic — item.information
text: Calculates item information statistics (McDonald, 1999).

title: McDonald's item information statistic — item.information
code: item.information(x)

title: McDonald's item information statistic — item.information
text: x data frame containing items

title: McDonald's item information statistic — item.information
text: matrix containing item () unstandardized factor loading, (b) square loading, (c) unique variance, (d) item information.

title: McDonald's item information statistic — item.information
code: library(lordif) #> Error in library(lordif): there is no package called ‘lordif’ data(Anxiety) #> Warning: data set ‘Anxiety’ not found info <- item.information(Anxiety[4:32]) #> Error in loadNamespace(x): there is no package called ‘psych’ info #> Error: object 'info' not found

code: item.reliability.index(x)

title: Gulliksen's item reliability index extended to polytomous items — item.reliability.index
text: x data frame contains items analysed

title: Gulliksen's item reliability index extended to polytomous items — item.reliability.index
text: item reliability index item

title: Gulliksen's item reliability index extended to polytomous items — item.reliability.index
code: #Calculate item reliability indexes for the items of the Neuroticism Scale of the bfi data set library(psychTools) #> Error in library(psychTools): there is no package called ‘psychTools’ data(bfi) #> Warning: data set ‘bfi’ not found item.reliability.index(bfi[16:20]) #> Error in loadNamespace(x): there is no package called ‘psych’

what: Selecting items based on Gulliksen's item reliability index — item.selection
title: Selecting items based on Gulliksen's item reliability index — item.selection
text: Iteratively removes item lowest item reliability index pool items. step yields test largest possible variance.

title: Selecting items based on Gulliksen's item reliability index — item.selection
code: item.selection(x, nitems)

title: Selecting items based on Gulliksen's item reliability index — item.selection
text: x data frame contains items analysed nitems number items retain. value never less three.

title: Selecting items based on Gulliksen's item reliability index — item.selection
text: step number items removed, name last item removed, omega, average item score, standard deviation test.

title: Selecting items based on Gulliksen's item reliability index — item.selection
code: #Calculate item reliability indexes for the items of the Neuroticism Scale of the bfi data set library(psychTools) #> Error in library(psychTools): there is no package called ‘psychTools’ data(bfi) #> Warning: data set ‘bfi’ not found item.selection(bfi[16:20], 3) #> Error in loadNamespace(x): there is no package called ‘psych’

title: Large factor analysis residuals — large.residuals
text: Identifying large residuals matrix factor analysis residuals

title: Large factor analysis residuals — large.residuals
code: large.residuals(x, upper = 0.08, lower = -0.08)

title: Large factor analysis residuals — large.residuals
text: x square matrix residuals factor analysis upper Upper limit acceptable residuals (defaults 0.08) lower Lower limit acceptable residuals (defaults -0.)

title: Large factor analysis residuals — large.residuals
text: Statistics relating residuals

title: Large factor analysis residuals — large.residuals
code: library(psychTools) #> Error in library(psychTools): there is no package called ‘psychTools’ data(bfi) #> Warning: data set ‘bfi’ not found myresiduals <- psych::fa(bfi[1:10], nfactors = 2)$resid #> Error in loadNamespace(x): there is no package called ‘psych’ myoutput <- large.residuals(x = myresiduals) #> Error: object 'myresiduals' not found myoutput #> Error: object 'myoutput' not found

what: Create norms for psychological or educational tests — make.norms
title: Create norms for psychological or educational tests — make.norms
text: Creates percentiles, McCall T-scores (M = 50, SD = 10) stanines (M = 5, SD = 2)

title: Create norms for psychological or educational tests — make.norms
code: make.norms(xsum)

title: Create norms for psychological or educational tests — make.norms
text: xsum vector raw total scores test (missing data)

title: Create norms for psychological or educational tests — make.norms
code: # Create norms for the Neuroticism Scale of the bfi library(psych) #> Error in library(psych): there is no package called ‘psych’ data(bfi) #> Warning: data set ‘bfi’ not found bfi <- na.omit(bfi) #> Error: object 'bfi' not found Ntotal <- rowSums(bfi[16:20])   #> Error: object 'bfi' not found  make.norms(Ntotal) #> Error: object 'Ntotal' not found

title: Reverse code items — reverse.code
text: Reflects scoring items

title: Reverse code items — reverse.code
code: reverse.code(x, min.score, max.score, items)

title: Reverse code items — reverse.code
text: x Data frame containing items, may need reverse coded min.score Minimum possible score items max.score Maximum possible score items items vector item names column numbers items need reverse coded

title: Reverse code items — reverse.code
text: data frame

title: Reverse code items — reverse.code
code: library(psychTools) #> Error in library(psychTools): there is no package called ‘psychTools’ data(bfi) #> Warning: data set ‘bfi’ not found  ## Perform principal components analysis to observe the signs of the component loadings psych::pca(bfi[1:25], 5) #> Error in loadNamespace(x): there is no package called ‘psych’ items <- c("A1", "C4", "C5", "E1", "E2", "O2", "O5") bfi.new <- reverse.code(bfi[1:25], min.score = 1, max.score = 6, items) #> Error: object 'bfi' not found psych::pca(bfi.new[1:25], 5) #> Error in loadNamespace(x): there is no package called ‘psych’
